headline: Jack Dorsey’s Block to Lay Off 40% of Its Workforce in AI Remake
summary: Block  the payments company founded by  Jack Dorsey  that includes Square and Cash App, said Thursday that it plans to lay off 40% of its workforce, or more than 4,000 employees.  Dorsey alluded to artificial-intelligence tools as the reason for the cuts in a letter to shareholders.  “The core thesis is simple,” wrote Dorsey.

content.title: Jack Dorsey’s Block to Lay Off 40% of Its Workforce in AI Remake
content.summary: Block  the payments company founded by  Jack Dorsey  that includes Square and Cash App, said Thursday that it plans to lay off 40% of its workforce, or more than 4,000 employees.  Dorsey alluded to artificial-intelligence tools as the reason for the cuts in a letter to shareholders.  “The core thesis is simple,” wrote Dorsey.

headline: Asian shares are mixed after Nvidia's losses pull Wall St lower, as AI-linked layoffs rattle markets
summary: Shares were mixed Friday in Asia after the worst day for Nvidia’s stock since last spring dragged U.S. stocks lower.  U.S. futures fell as investors focused on comments by Block CEO Jack Dorsey on his company’s decision to lay off 40% of its workforce because of labor-saving artificial intelligence.

content.title: Asian shares are mixed after Nvidia's losses pull Wall St lower, as AI-linked layoffs rattle markets

U.S. futures fell as investors focused on comments by Block CEO Jack Dorsey on his company’s decision to lay off 40% of its workforce because of labor-saving artificial intelligence.

thumbnail.caption: Currency traders watch monitors near a screen showing the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI), top center, and the foreign exchange rate between U.S. dollar and South Korean won, top center left, at the foreign exchange dealing room of the Hana Bank headquarters, in Seoul, South Korea, Friday, Feb. 27, 2026. (AP Photo/Ahn Young-joon)

headline: Nvidia Fails to Reassure—Heard on the Street Thursday Recap
summary: Nvidia’s shares fell 5.5% despite record income as investors continue to set a high bar for AI bellwethers.  One problem, notes Heard columnist Dan Gallagher, is that the company’s runaway success could be seen as a sign of destabilization to come, given that the capital spending filling its coffers is financially weakening some of the world’s largest companies, from Amazon to Microsoft.  The Nasdaq and S&P 500 declined following Nvidia's slide, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average was little changed and Treasury yields inched lower.

content.title: Nvidia Fails to Reassure—Heard on the Street Thursday Recap

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 declined following Nvidia's slide, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average was little changed and Treasury yields inched lower.

headline: Jack Dorsey’s Block Slashes Nearly Half Its Staff in AI Bet
summary: Block has been restructuring its business model and staffing since 2024 as the company’s stock has lagged.  At the same time, the company has invested heavily in AI tools to run more efficiently, including building its own tool called Goose.

content.title: Jack Dorsey’s Block Slashes Nearly Half Its Staff in AI Bet
content.summary: Block has been restructuring its business model and staffing since 2024 as the company’s stock has lagged.  At the same time, the company has invested heavily in AI tools to run more efficiently, including building its own tool called Goose.

headline: Software companies need 'innovative DNA' to not just exist, but grow
summary: Software stocks are staging a recovery this trading week from this month's sell-offs fueled by new AI concerns, an event Wall Street is dubbing the "SaaS-pocalypse." Is this good news here to stay for software companies or should they expect more trouble ahead? Guggenheim Securities senior research analyst and senior managing director of software, John DiFucci, gives a history lesson on software innovation and growth by comparing a company like Salesforce (CRM) to that of Computer Associates. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

content.title: Software companies need 'innovative DNA' to not just exist, but grow
content.description:
Software stocks are staging a recovery this trading week from this month's sell-offs fueled by new AI concerns, an event Wall Street is dubbing the "SaaS-pocalypse." Is this good news here to stay for software companies or should they expect more trouble ahead?

Guggenheim Securities senior research analyst and senior managing director of software, John DiFucci, gives a history lesson on software innovation and growth by comparing a company like Salesforce (CRM) to that of Computer Associates.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

headline: Salesforce Pushes Deeper Into AI Agents With Momentum And Agentforce
summary: Salesforce (NYSE:CRM) is acquiring Momentum to expand AI driven conversational insights across its Agentforce 360 platform and Slack. The deal is paired with rapid enterprise uptake of Agentforce and new partner integrations that automate document workflows and hybrid workforce coordination. These developments position Salesforce as an early mover in AI powered, agent based workflows across large organizations. For investors tracking NYSE:CRM, this move comes as Salesforce shares trade...

headline: The Dow’s ‘Citrini Selloff’ Is Back. Blame Block.
summary: Block’s mass layoffs reignited Wall Street’s paranoia about artificial intelligence advancements. The Dow fell 588 points, or 1.2%. The S&P 500 was down 0.6%. The Nasdaq Composite was down 0.8%. Among the hardest hit stocks in the Dow were American Express, Goldman Sachs Group, Salesforce, and JPMorgan Chase.

content.title: The Dow’s ‘Citrini Selloff’ Is Back. Blame Block.
content.summary: Block’s mass layoffs reignited Wall Street’s paranoia about artificial intelligence advancements. The Dow fell 588 points, or 1.2%. The S&P 500 was down 0.6%. The Nasdaq Composite was down 0.8%. Among the hardest hit stocks in the Dow were American Express, Goldman Sachs Group, Salesforce, and JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Dow Is on Pace for Its Worst Week of the Year
summary: The Dow is having its worst week of the year.  The blue-chip index is down 725 points, or 1.5% this week, which would be its largest decline on a percent and point basis since the week of Nov. 21, 2025, according to Dow Jones Market Data.  Friday’s slide was led by American Express, Goldman Sachs, Salesforce, JPMorgan Chase.

Friday’s slide was led by American Express, Goldman Sachs, Salesforce, JPMorgan Chase.

headline: This analyst isn't buying into software's existential risk narrative
summary: Macquarie US head of software and services research Steve Koenig weighs in on the state of the software industry amid recent AI-fueled sell-offs — which Salesforce (CRM) and experts have dubbed as the "SaaS-pocalyspe", "Software-mageddon", or "SaaSquatch" — and whether he is believing narratives that software is facing serious existential risks. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.
